Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Enhance OData deprecation error message" (#8242) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Progress on https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3428 There are two variants of error messages because the `/api/v1/Packages()` endpoint will be entirely disabled (it does not hijack at all) and will therefore need different wording than the rest of the endpoints which just have some sets of parameter combinations disabled. ### `/api/v1/Packages` - endpoint disabled ``` https://localhost/api/v1/Packages()?$orderby=Version ``` Response with formatting (my browser): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/95260367-6f376400-07dd-11eb-8ec3-e0b296a98fe4.png) Response without formatting (most likely experience): <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><m:error xmlns:m="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/metadata"><m:code /><m:message xml:lang="en-US">This OData endpoint is disabled. Please refer to the following URL for more information about this deprecation: https://aka.ms/nuget/odata-deprecation</m:message></m:error> ### All other non-hijacked queries - combinations of parameters disabled ``` https://localhost/api/v2/FindPackagesById()?id=%27Newtonsoft.Json%27&$orderby=Version ``` Response with formatting: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/95260626-ea007f00-07dd-11eb-857e-f93351bb923a.png) Response without formatting (most likely experience): <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?><m:error xmlns:m="http://schemas.microsoft.com/ado/2007/08/dataservices/metadata"><m:code /><m:message xml:lang="en-US">The combination of parameters provided to this OData endpoint is not supported. Please refer to the following URL for more information about this deprecation: https://aka.ms/nuget/odata-deprecation</m:message></m:error> ### Notes - I could not find a good way to pretty format the XML with indentation or whitespace - The link currently points to the root blog URL but will be fixed up to point to a real blog post/doc prior to the feature flags being used.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add a skip list when generating the "Add Reference" database" (#8245) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Visual Studio can recommend installing a package if you reference a type from that package. Today, there's no way to opt-out a package from being added to the "Add Reference" database. This is problematic as some recommendations are known to be incorrect (see https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8243). It would be better to simply skip recommendations from packages we incorrectly index.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add a skip list for packages that shouldn't be added to the "Add Reference" database.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The "Add Reference" database can recommend the wrong package for PackageReference projects" (#8243) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Bug description

The "Add Reference" database may recommend the wrong package for projects that use `PackageReference`. This happens only when a package's `ref` folder does not align with its `lib` folder. Usage of the "ref" folder is quite low in the NuGet ecosystem at this time (~10K packages out of ~3.1M)

### Reproduction steps

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/737941/95372612-a155ce00-0890-11eb-87d2-e87605158a60.png)

1. Reference the `BasicHttpBinding` type in your C# project
1. Open Visual Studio's suggestion, see that it recommends installing [`System.Private.ServiceModel`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Private.ServiceModel/) (instead of [`System.ServiceModel.Http`](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.ServiceModel.Http))
1. Install the `System.Private.ServiceModel` package
1. Build your project. If you use `PackageReference` to reference NuGet packages, your build will fail. However, if you use `packages.config` to reference NuGet packages, your build will pass.

### Expected behavior
The code that creates the "Add Reference" database only looks at packages' "lib" folders and ignores the "ref" folders. This was correct when only `packages.config` existed, but we need to revisit that logic to reflect `PackageReference`'s behavior.

In this scenario above, `System.Private.ServiceModel` has an empty "refs" folder, thereby hiding all its types. The `System.ServiceModel.Http` package exposes these types using its "refs" folder and by depending on `System.Private.ServiceModel`.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Make PM UI's icon display resilient to errors" (#10116) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
It appears we have had multiple bugs in the past related to icons in PM UI which caused VS to crash: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9696, https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10037

PM UI should never crash VS. If there's any kind of problem with displaying an icon, NuGet should display the default icon.

I'm not sure about the first issue, but the second issue is caused because WPF's implementation of resizing and changing the color pallet of images happens on the Dispatcher (UI) thread, and doesn't catch exceptions. Unhandled exceptions on the UI thread crashes the process. Since this is work that WPF is scheduling on the UI thread, NuGet's not on the call stack, and hence we cannot catch/handle the exception. The Dispatcher.UnhandledException handler does get triggered, but I don't see any way to determine if it was NuGet, or something else, that triggered the image load, and even if we assume it was NuGet, I'm not sure how to determine which image load had the problem when we load multiple images in parallel.

Even if dotnet/wpf fixes the issue, that will take effect in .NET 6 at the earliest, but VS 2019 runs in .NET Framework 4.7.2 (or 4.8 if that's installed, I guess). The bar to service the .NET Framework is very, very high, so I have no idea if this issue would be approved. Even if it is, customers who haven't installed the patch would continue to crash. We have to decide what machine install states we want to support.

We should investigating re-designing our icon loading code so that crashing VS just cannot happen, even for bugs we don't currently know about. Think `catch (Exception e)`, rather than catching specific exceptions, which is normally the recommendation. This won't work for this WPF exception on dispatcher thread issue, so we need to do something in addition to handle that scenario.

I have no idea if it will work, but maybe we can copy [WPF's code](https://github.com/dotnet/wpf/blob/b697746306a695af80a756586cad3f84a62e366c/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Wpf/src/PresentationCore/System/Windows/Media/Imaging/BitmapImage.cs#L303), and add more try-catch blocks.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget acceptance command works wrong!" (#9386) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | dotnet.exe):

NuGet version (5.4.0.2):

dotnet.exe --version (3.1.102):

OS version (Win10 v1903 (18362.720)):

When I run my dotnet nuget command in console like following:

`dotnet nuget delete B3.Extensions.Data 1.0.2 -s https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json -k apikey`

it asks me if I want to continue.

![e](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2901269/78363733-f30d5b00-75c4-11ea-88e0-4fc86767512d.PNG)

If I type "y", it is cancelling. If I type "n", it is deleting.

My language is Turkish. So there is a translation bug or logical bug here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "{CPVM] Add support for optional pack the pinned transitive dependencies." (#10115) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
One of the features that CPVM supports is enforcing transitive dependencies to the central defined versions. As all the testing and development for an application is done using the specified dependency set, on pack the enforced/pinned transitive dependencies are packed as well. 

However this may not be the desired experience for some of the scenarios. 

## Suggestion
Consider have an pack option to include the transitive dependencies only per request. 

Related with: https://github.com/openiddict/openiddict-core/issues/1113

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Design and cost Dotnet nuget sign" (#10090) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Unable to auto create nuspec file." (#10114) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm trying to generate `nuspec `manifest file from legacy _.NET Framework 4.5_ library project.
According to [MSDN documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/quickstart/create-and-publish-a-package-using-visual-studio-net-framework#generate-the-initial-manifest) I can create the manifest file by typing : 
```
nuget spec MyProject.csproj
```
This should create a `MyProject.nuspec` file filled with all my project metadata (assembly version, author..)
But when I examine the generated file, **no replacement token has been filled**.
My goal is to completely automate this step, so I don't want to manually fill anything.

## Details about Problem

NuGet Version: 5.7.0.6726
Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2019 (2) Version 16.7.4
OS version Windows 10 2004

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. `nuget spec MyProject.csproj`
2. The generated file looks like the bellow, without any replacement token filled.
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package >
  <metadata>
    <id>$id$</id>
    <version>$version$</version>
    <title>$title$</title>
    <authors>$author$</authors>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <license type="expression">MIT</license>
    <projectUrl>http://project_url_here_or_delete_this_line/</projectUrl>
    <iconUrl>http://icon_url_here_or_delete_this_line/</iconUrl>
    <description>$description$</description>
    <releaseNotes>Summary of changes made in this release of the package.</releaseNotes>
    <copyright>$copyright$</copyright>
    <tags>Tag1 Tag2</tags>
  </metadata>
</package>
```

## Other suggested things

Additionally, I've also tried to generate the nuspec file directly from the assembly by typing : 
```nuget spec -a bin\release\MyProject.dll```

In that case, some token were replaced but some strange dependencies were added.
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<package >
  <metadata>
    <id>DummyLib</id>
    <version>1.0.1</version>
    <authors>The Author</authors>
    <requireLicenseAcceptance>false</requireLicenseAcceptance>
    <license type="expression">MIT</license>
    <projectUrl>http://project_url_here_or_delete_this_line/</projectUrl>
    <iconUrl>http://icon_url_here_or_delete_this_line/</iconUrl>
    <description>Description</description>
    <releaseNotes>Summary of changes made in this release of the package.</releaseNotes>
    <copyright>$copyright$</copyright>
    <tags>Tag1 Tag2</tags>
    <dependencies>
      <group targetFramework=".NETStandard2.1">
        <dependency id="SampleDependency" version="1.0.0" />
      </group>
    </dependencies>
  </metadata>
</package>
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Making Restore for Older TFMs with TargetPlatformStrings" (#10113) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Nuget Restore started supporting net5.0-* TargetFrameworks, but it treat all the other older targetframeworks as  if there were without targetPlatform. 
eg restore works perfectly for this project
```csproj
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFrameworks>net5.0;net5.0-Windows</TargetFrameworks>
  </PropertyGroup>
</Project>
```
but the restore on the following project 
```csproj
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFrameworks>netcoreapp3.1;netcoreapp3.1-Windows</TargetFrameworks> -->
  </PropertyGroup>  
</Project>
```
results in 
```
NuGet.targets(130,5): error : Invalid restore input. Duplicate frameworks found: 'netcoreapp3.1, netcoreapp3.1'
```

##usage

We have using targetPlatforms in the runtime repo for a while now. This will help us in using the latest sdk and nuget feaures.
Currently the restore does not work in the VS for projects, it will help us rectify that as well.


cc @ericstj @ViktorHofer @safern

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[CPVM - PMUI] Error on the Browse tab for non-CPS projects" (#10089) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
Error on "Browse" tab in the PMUI for a non-CPS project CPVM enabled.  

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Download the attached file

2. Open the project in VisualStudio (Visual Studio version used: Version 16.8.0 Preview 4.0 [30518.12.main])

3. Build
